Given a linear operator expressed as a function mapping a vector to a vector,
is there a standard method for finding its matrix representation?
Is there something like just applying it to a basis one column at a time, and then concatenating the output?

text: Yes. Let $v_i$ be the column vector with zeros everywhere except 1 on the $i$-th entry. Then the matrix is just $\begin{pmatrix} | & | & & |\\ v_1 & v_2 & \cdots & v_n \\ | & | & & | \end{pmatrix}$

text: If you know that your linear operator is low rank k << n, or has quickly decaying singular values, you can perform a randomized svd with k matrix-vector-products rather than n. Depends on your operator though + how expensive it is to apply it.
